text: Thanks for reading, I'm Dean. Here is what I'm looking for, someone who has made a steady stream of income from stock trading, be it either for a living, or just side money. I say that because I have made side money, and a living at poker and sportsbetting. I very much want to learn about stocks. My parents are nearing retirement age and have not prepared for it at all. They are wonderful folks, but not good with money. I would like to learn enough to get them some things set up that will at least help. I have a lot of natural trend-noticing and high observational skills. I have good instincts and I operate on logic and reason, not emotions. With the right person's brain to pick, I think I could develop some competency in trading. In return, I would be happy to coach you on all things cards and sports-info related. If you're someone who actually wants to try and win when you play poker and sportsbet, and find those tiny advantages and small edges, I am that person. I don't gamble, I play are skill games. Games where statistics, recent history, trends, psychology, weather, indicators, and to a degree, luck, all play a factor in the outcome or result. Sounds a lot like stocks huh? I have a deep understanding of poker, on the psychological and subconscious levels. I can tell you why players do certain things that they don't even understand why they do. Its all behavioral training and the fact most people are naturally uncomfortable lying, and in poker, lying (bluffing) is mandatory. Anyway, point is, I think we could have more than a fair trade on brainpicking if this is something that interests any stocks aficionados. This would be over skype/phone as I'm posting this in multiple cities. I am posting this in women AND men, because it doesn't matter to me. I will say however, these skills are SO much more valuable to women, but most of them don't realize it. Put your city in the line so I know you read the whole thing. title: Underwear Review
text:
Hey guys! It's been a couple of weeks since my last review....I'm running out of underwear to review. I need to go shopping. Thanks to all of you who have "checked in" on me this week. I haven't fallen of the face of the earth...just busier than I've ever been. I've taken on a position in our city government, but it's all good.
This weeks review I'm super excited about, Duluth Trading's 'Buck Naked' underwear. Now if the name doesn't make you want to order a pair, then hopefully my review will.
Duluth Trading has done a good job in their advertising, targeting their brand to the average 'bear looking' guy. Then the ads all stopped and people like me turn to their website which leaves a trail of cookies right back to our computers. In my opinion, that's good advertising.
So yes, I ordered a pair and I'm so glad I did. The fabric is a honeycomb weave nylon. Now Usually don't like a fabric without at least some percentage of cotton, nylon gives me a rash or at the very least makes me feel like I'm scratching my balls off. But with this unusual weave makes them as comfortable as cotton. Their claim is "no sweat, no stink, no pinch" and they are true to their claim. When I got mine in the mail I immediately put them on and wore them the rest of that day, wore them to bed that night. Then decided to wear them the following day and night. And they are true to their claim.....they felt and smelled clean enough the wear them again the next day (but I didn't).
The construction is top notch....double and 3 needle sewing. The style is somewhat old man looking, but the real treat to these u/w is the gusset through the crotch area. A double layer of fabric sewn in across the crotch. This causes a gentle lift the the balls without forcing them into a pouch. I just bought myself a truck ..... I have to lift myself up into the seat and if I'm not careful my balls will get under a leg and I end up sitting on them, even with a pouch. Buck Naked keeps everyting in place.
I only have two things against these U/W, one being the "old man" style and the other is that the rise is just a bit too high. Now I don't like low rise, but I don't want them up to my belly button either.
I HIGHLY recommend this brand....I think you guys will like them too.
A shout out to George .... I haven't got to talk to you in a while...but I think about you every day.
I love talking to all of you...keep the feedback coming.
I love you and there ain't nothing you can do about it.

title: MWM seeks femal email buddy
text:
Let me start by saying that I'm 43 years old and married with kids. I work in the city, have a long commute and struggle to find time to spend with my family, so that's my priority when I'm home. Having said that, I do find the wake-train-work-kids-sleep-repeat cycle wears on me sometimes and I find myself craving a break from my reality. I'm thinking having an email buddy to share life's ups and downs or just talk about whatever comes up would provide just that sort of mental break from everyday life. I guess I'd just love to find a good friend that's just for me and a place to go to discuss whatever I need or want to with no judgement or pretense. Out of necessity this friendship will be a secret, I wouldn't expect my wife to understand and she would naturally be concerned. 

I'm not quite how to get this started but I'm open to friends any sort, though I think a female most definitely fits best for this purpose. However, age, race, looks, location are of no importance for this purpose. Please just be mature (most of the time, ha!) and able to hold up your end of a grown up conversation.

I think I should probably give you a quick look into my makeup so you can make an educated decision whether to take a leap and send a reply. I've thought some about how to do that but settled on a simple stream of consciousness, forgive me if it seems random and a bit trivial, but it's the best I can do here:

I love to read and my library card is one of my prize possessions
Some of my best childhood memories involve trips to the library with my mom. 
I take my boys to our library frequently and hope they'll have some of those same great memories.
I've grown a little more adventurous with food as I've aged and had a chance to travel. Though I still refuse to eat certain basics that you will find strange. 
My boys are my world and I take very seriously the responsibility of raising them. 
I desperately hope I'll be able to help mold them into responsible, respectful, kind, compassionate yet independent and strong young men. 
My favorite thing is to coach them in their various park district sports. Those practices and games are the most fun I have these days. 
I work in finance and have a somewhat stressful job and long commute. It is rewarding at times but also the source of my biggest regret, the time that it takes me away from home. 
Even though I work in finance, math has always been a weakness. I work hard not to let that show. 
I spend an hour each way on the train and hope you will help me fill that time with some interesting conversation. 
I try to be transparent and do my best not to judge others and I'm almost impossible to offend. 
Im organizationally challenged at times and as a result can seem non responsive or unconcerned with timeliness or deadlines. I'm working on that. Ha! 

That's probably enough for now. If you've managed to get through this entire email and still have some interest, please send a reply!

title: Secret letters
text:
You approach the magazine rack briskly, the anticipation eating at you since you received the text that another letter was waiting for you. The mysterious man you have never met has a way of ramping up your desires and emotions. Stirring passions in you that your husband never could. It's become a delicious addiction, a drug doled out at his convenience, not yours. It's been two weeks since his last letter, the one that left you breathless, satisfied but crazy with amazement and exhilaration. Scanning the disheveled magazines you find the row of Cosmopolitan. Hidden behind in a plain white envelope is the letter. You snatch it quickly before anyone comes towards you and discreetly place it in your purse. Off to grab a gallon of milk and race home to make dinner, do a load of laundry, help with homework, and whatever mundane, monotonous evening tasks come your way. On the way home you keep sneaking peeks at your purse, wishing you had the time to read it, feel his words, follow his commands, and lust for his touch, his kisses, the scent of his skin, having him inside you and never letting go.

The soft snore from your husband is the clue you've been waiting for, he's finally asleep. Nothing short of an earthquake will wake him now. You know because for years you have tried. Placing the book you were reading on the night stand, you turn off your reading light, sit and smile for a moment and think of him. You remember the one time you heard his voice, how gentle but manly the tone of his voice was, how it aroused you. You want to break the rules. The rules you both made in the beginning. No exchanging pictures, no real names, no meeting in person, no contact via text unless he texts first. All you know is he is married, has kids, and lives in the same town as you. He's in his forties, and has had a spell on you and it has changed your life for the better.

Reaching quietly beneath the bed you feel for your purse. Finally feeling the envelope you clutch it tight to your side. You creep down the stairs to the kitchen, make a cup of sleepy tea, your cover should anyone awaken and wonder why you are up. You head to the family room, sit on the couch close to the lamp and place your tea on end table. Finally, a moment to yourself to enjoy. You take the throw blanket on the arm rest and cover yourself, knowing what you will probably end up doing reading his words. You gently open the letter, take it out, unfold it and begin to read...

If you like what you've read and want to know what reply was in the letter please respond. Tell me why I should share that with you. Thanks :)

PS I'm very real

title: Drive For Our Bike Ride, Cross the USA for Free!
text:
I didn't know where to post this because we are looking for something different, as you will see. I listed a zip code because Craigslist required it.

We are two bicycle riders who plan on riding across the USA, from San Francisco to St. Petersburg, Florida, starting in June 2016 and ending mid to late August. (Yes, we know it will be HOT, but that it is when drivers are most likely available.)

We are looking for a c0-driver for a support vehicle (we already have a local 29 year old woman and she would like some company along the way) We will pay your travel, lodging, entertainment and food expenses during the trip. 

You will arrive in the San Francisco Bay Area where we are and we will drive to Los Angeles a few days before the June 14 start of our bike ride so that you can do some seeing there. In Los Angeles you will experience such sights as the Pacific Ocean, Venice Beach (a uniquely California experience), Korea Town, Hollywood and Beverly Hills. We then ride towards Palm Springs and on to the Grand Canyon (a wonder of the world and photos really do not do it justice). From there we will travel through such places as Flagstaff and Sedona, Arizona, Albuquerque, New Mexico (with its Native American culture), Santa Fe (one of the art capitals of the world), Carlsbad Caverns, Austin (probably the most progressive city in Texas), San Antonio (home of the Alamo and its river walk which doesn't rival Venice but is nonetheless fun), Baton Rouge, New Orleans (home of Cajun cooking and Mardi Gras) and finally St. Augustine (the oldest continuously occupied European settlement in the US). We will spend rest and visiting days in the more interesting places so it won't be just a "drive by" experience.

There will be boring stretches of vast expanses, but more importantly, you will have the chance to see more small town "Americana" than most Americans get to see while experiencing Tex-Mex food, parts of the "Old West," Louisiana, Florida and much more. We will take a different route driving back across the country to see different places, probably including Las Vegas. When we return to the San Francisco Bay Area you will get to see, of course, the Golden Gate Bridge, it's beautiful views, Sausalito, the Berkeley campus, and more if you want. 

Because the two of us will be riding our bikes going to Florida, your driving will only be from 100km to at most 200km (60 to, at the most, 115 miles) per day, with some days off for our rest and to visit places of interest. We would like you to do laundry once a week or so while we are riding as well as some food shopping and preparation (lunches, such as sandwiches) and help with planning our lodging and stops.

You need to be good natured, responsible, easy to get along with, speak English, have a valid driver's license and be able to get a visa to visit the USA if a visa is required. This is perfect for a college student, a recent graduate who doesn't yet have a job or possibly a teacher who wants to spend vacation time exploring.

In the photo, I am 2nd from the right and Nick is 4th from the right. 

We are 2 responsible professional men who live near San Francisco.

Let us know if you are interested.

Thank you, and here is to the adventure of a life time,

Rick

title: Seeking 30-something, educated, sane
text:
Over the years, I've had a couple of very pleasant extended interactions with women I've met via Craigslist. As you might imagine, this hasn't come easily. I've posted quite a few times, and most of the responses have been somehow off the mark. Sometimes respondents have been looking for a different kind of interaction; many times there has been a simple lack of chemistry; and, because it's CL, frequently the problem has been sheer lunacy on the part of the respondent.

With that history in mind, I think I can do a better job of articulating what I'm looking for and which type of woman might be the best fit for me in this endeavor. Please note: I'm not offering any kind of authoritative global commentary on what's "right" or "good" here; I'm merely stating what works for me -- an admittedly imperfect person. I respect the fact that it might not appeal to everyone, but I'm probably not interested in having an extended argument about how misguided or unfair I am. 

First, a little about me: I am an academic in my late 40s. I'm married and have a couple of kids. I am generally content with this situation. Truth be told, I'm not desperately unhappy. However, I find myself somewhat restless, and looking for sustained connections online. My goal in doing this isn't to engage in a torrid physical affair (more on that later) but rather to find steady electronic interaction (mainly via email) with someone who stimulates me intellectually, emotionally, and physically. Only one or two email per day probably won't be sufficient to hold my interest. And -- despite the length of this posting -- I'm usually not someone who writes a short essay with each response. I'm looking for short but fairly steady contact (knowing, of course, that sometimes life gets in the way and one can't always respond immediately).

My partners in this kind of interaction invariably have been younger -- usually women in the 32-40 age range. I am not sure why this is --honestly I'm not obsessed with the idea of connecting with a "younger woman" -- but I have found it to be comfortable. Also, they have been reasonably well educated and engaged in professional careers. (No, I won't be expecting to see a resume, but there will be more common ground with someone in a white collar occupation.) I'm a fit, active person, and I'd prefer someone who is similarly inclined (runner, yogi practitioner, etc.), or at least fits into the "HWP" category. There are some other characteristics that I value, but they seem rather generic and subjective: sense of humor, literacy, taste in music, books, wine, etc. 

Finally, regarding the possibility of meeting in person: It's not my primary goal. Furthermore, I'm posting this ad outside the area where I actually reside, so it would be extremely difficult to pull off. However, with the right person and under the perfect set of circumstances, I would entertain the possibility.

But first, let's email.

title: I Am Really Not Sure What I Want ?
text:
Not Sure What I Want ?

I have posted on CL before . . .

I am just not sure what I want, are you ?

I have posted for just romance and nothing else and got some responses, but nothing worked out.

I have been tempted to answer, in fact I have, some of the posts for FWB and Let's DO IT not sure what to expect ?

That was an even bigger failure than the Romance Post plan.

Let me say that I AM married, that will never change for reasons I will not get into right away. Life can be complicated and sometimes you have to fulfill your obligations even if it means enormous compromise.

But at the same time, if I cannot live life and be me . . . then I am cheating myself and everyone around me. I know this sounds very selfish and self centered. Sorry I have to still live and breathe and see the world around me.

There is alot I desire, there is alot I miss, there is so much I want to experience again, and yet I know I must just be patient and take things very, very slow.

I have had a few things happen in my life that brought me to this place and if I found someone who truly wanted to know I would share some of this.

So where do we draw the line ? What is OK and what is not ?

I am also not vanilla ice cream by any stretch of the imagination, not that this may come into play with whatever may come from this,

What that means, and it is a very wide ranging topic, is that I crave passion and kissing and more, but NOT the typical Craigslist Quick Hook Up, in fact I am not sure fucking will be a part of this, although there are so many things I do crave and wish to explore with another who, like me, knows there is more and either is aware or not sure that more is or means.. I will just have to hope that YOU, if there is a YOU out there get this . . . even if only conceptually.

The only way you are still reading this is if you are feeling some commonality or curiosity. This will not be tame, but it is not about anything to be afraid of either, in fact what we crave is excitement beyond the simple that most are satisfied with.

I am not a simple person, even though what I think that I want is quite simple. If you are easily embarrassed or offended this may not be for you, since I want to push things to the very edge, but only out here in the safety of cyber-space at first. So there is very little to fear or worry about.

I know I have not been very clear in what I am looking for or what I want, thus the title, remember the subject line of this post ?

I am hoping you partially get it and have been wondering the same thing about yourself, or are after reading this.

So if you feel the same reply NOW, please put " I am not sure either " in your subject line so I know it is a sincere reply

Then you better buckle up, cause it may be a very wild ride, if we do it right ?

OH yes I really would like to know who I am talking to, I hate to do this it is so shallow, but I really have a thing about eyes and I need all the rest too, I read people and your detailed description of you will help me hear you and feel you.

A couple of things, you should be over 18, but beyond that your age is meaningless to me. I prefer a woman who is shaped like a woman, this does not mean you have to be a Barbie Doll, but you have to be somewhat smaller in the middle that the top and bottom and I apologize if this is not you, but it is what works for me. Just to be clear BBW won't work for me, sorry to be blunt. You need to live in the DFW area, if you are outside the area, this is an exercise in futility, unless you travel here OFTEN or something like that.

So are you the ONE that read this whole post and "get's it" if so . . . . ANSWER ME NOW . . . . RIGHT NOW . . . . IMMEDIATELY . . . . Please !

Tell me "I am not sure either" write to me, talk to me, email me, Hurry, I am waiting for YOU !

title: ***** PART-TIME ENTREPRENEUR *****
text:
Have you ever felt like something was just not right with the world? As if you've been living a lie? If you ever seen The Matrix movies, then you know what I'm talking about.

Not saying that we all live in a computer generated world, but I do believe that metaphorically speaking, we do live in a Matrix. Some of the realities are created by other people, organizations and institutions. . .others are created by our own perception of things.

We've been conditioned to believe that only the 'lucky ones' achieve their dreams. . .that only a chosen few will be able to do what they want, when they want and with whom they want.

I call b.s. on that!

Because I have been awakened and I 'unplugged' from the Matrix, I see the world in abundance instead of lack. Now, are there real-life real-world problems out here? 

Absolutely! 

But don't get it twisted. . .we each have the power to make major changes in the world. . .but it starts with empowering ourselves, first and foremost.

With the help of fellow empowering part-time (and full-time) entrepreneurs, I get to impact thousands of people's lives from anywhere I choose as long as I have an internet connection.

If you are still reading this, then you may be the person I'm looking to lock arms with. But before I continue, let's take a trip down memory lane. . .

I was born in D.C., but grew up in Hampton Virginia. Growing up, the focus in my family was to go to school, get good grades, and find a high paying job. Pursing my passions was secondary to making sure I had education that would at least land me a safe and secure job.

You and I both know that there is no such thing as job security. And even if there were such a thing. . .it does not guarantee FINANCIAL security. 

As I learned in Robert Kiyosaki's book Rich Dad Poor Dad, it's not about how much you make, but how much you KEEP.

But I digress. . .so, through most of my scholastic years, I had been an honor roll student. It wasn't until my freshman year at James Madison University did I experience my first major failure. . .long story short; I got academically suspended and could not return for a calendar year.

I felt like a loser. . .how does one go from an A-B honor student to academic suspension? On the outside looking in, it would appear that the only way it could happen is from me simply not caring at all about my education...and that was far from the truth.

It was a shock to my ego, I'll admit. My friends asked were my parents furious at me because I failed so miserably. It was a surprise (even for me) to find out that they weren't furious at all. Perhaps disappointed, but that is my guess because they never expressed disappointment with me for doing so poorly in college.

But this goes a back to the Matrix thing. . ..my perception was that I was a loser, a failure, and that my parents were disappointed with me. . .all because of the expectations I had set for myself.

Fast-forward to 1996, when I decided to serve in the U.S. Navy after a year off from school and working a part-time job as a dessert prep/dishwasher. 

I basically still owed tuition to JMU as well has had to start paying back on the student loan (which wasn't even enough to cover the full tuition in the first place). 

Most of my buddies had gone into the service in other branches, so I figured the military couldn't be that bad.

I had a great time in the military; traveling the world, meeting different kinds of people. . .little did I know that this experience planted the seed of traveling as a lifestyle. 

Some of the places I traveled to were Colombia, Jamaica, Venezuela, Aruba, Germany, England, Denmark, Halifax and many more!

I used the time in the Navy to pay off my student debt as well as learn some skills in advanced electronics. I got honorably discharged after serving six years of service. After serving my time I decided to come back home to Virginia.

In 2002, I began work as a shipbuilder, doing electrician work. In the following years, I went from working outside in the elements to being in a climate-controlled cubicle. You would've thought I had 'made it.'

That was far from the truth.

I was not fulfilled.

I witnessed first-hand the office politics and was not down with it.

I have always been a free-spirited person. I do not do well with rules that don't make sense to me. To blindly do things just because 'they said so' never flew with me...especially when I found better ways of doing things.

I soon realized that just because it makes sense, doesn't necessarily mean that we're doing it that way. . .it seemed as if less things made more sense, the more we did them.

Have you had this experience at your job? If so, then you can feel my pain.

It wasn't until after reading Rich Dad Poor Dad in 2007 did the "entrepreneurial bug" bite me. I knew there was more to life than working the 40-40-40 Plan (40 hours a week, for 40 years only to get a retirement check 40% of what I'm making now. . .which wasn't enough in the first place), but did not know exactly how to go about looking.

Reading that book opened my eyes to how the money game actually works. I found out why the rich get richer, the poor get poorer and why the middle-class is getting wiped out.

I made a DECISION to make a change.

It was time to let go of the old ways of thinking I had adopted from my elders (no fault of theirs. . .they didn't know what they didn't know and did the best they could with what they had, and I thank them for it).

After a brief dabble into real estate investing, I got introduced to the home based business industry. . .I've been hooked ever since. Now, it didn't come without challenges; and I've had my fair share. 

To name a few:
-I racked up over $70,000 in debt
-I lost my home to foreclosure
-I got my car repossessed twice in a year
-I got my lights shut off every 3 months for a year

As you can see, even though I was making decent money, I wasn't keeping much of it. A lot of it went to over-draft fees, late fees, living beyond my means via credit cards, etc.

I was pretty reckless with my money. I'm sure you know a couple of folks who've been reckless with their funds as well.

There are a lot of things I want to do. I have dreams of becoming financially free; to travel the world and learn different cultures; to take cruises and spend days on the beaches of the world under blue skies and palm trees.

I want to create MY OWN economy without having to depend on a job to do these things. . .and I don't want to have to wait 40 years to save up, only to have the freedom, but not the body to enjoy my freedom, if you know what I mean, ;-)

And the best part of creating wealth is the ability to give more. I'm not breaking the bank (yet) but I have tasted what I feels like to earn income leveraging the internet in a way that I don't have to be present for every transaction.

I am building a business while having a life!

I'm not ashamed to say that I currently still work my 9-5, because I know that if my company were to let me go that I already have something in place working for me on my behalf (even as I type this message you're reading).

To have that peace of mind is priceless! I can now go to work without the stress. . .I can deal with the politics because I know that these shenanigans are temporary.

If you want to know more about my challenges and how I overcame them, feel free to reply to this post; holla at me.


Send me a message and tell me what YOUR DREAMS are and how making an extra income online will help you and your family.

I do read all of my messages because I do care. . .but I cannot want something for you more than yourself. I'm not the type to think I'm too good to answer messages. I was once in your shoes and I remember where I came from.

Now...if you message me with some b.s., you may not get a response from me, so keep it platonic.

Your future self and your dreams are waiting for you; when will you make a decision to meet up with them? It's time to get unplugged.

Peace,
~Valentino

title: MWM seeks femal email buddy
text:
Let me start by saying that I'm 43 years old and married with kids. I work in the city, have a long commute and struggle to find time to spend with my family, so that's my priority when I'm home. Having said that, I do find the wake-train-work-kids-sleep-repeat cycle wears on me sometimes and I find myself craving a break from my reality. I'm thinking having an email buddy to share life's ups and downs or just talk about whatever comes up would provide just that sort of mental break from everyday life. I guess I'd just love to find a good friend that's just for me and a place to go to discuss whatever I need or want to with no judgement or pretense. Out of necessity this friendship will be a secret, I wouldn't expect my wife to understand and she would naturally be concerned. 

I'm not quite how to get this started but I'm open to friends any sort, though I think a female most definitely fits best for this purpose. However, age, race, looks, location are of no importance for this purpose. Please just be mature (most of the time, ha!) and able to hold up your end of a grown up conversation.

I think I should probably give you a quick look into my makeup so you can make an educated decision whether to take a leap and send a reply. I've thought some about how to do that but settled on a simple stream of consciousness, forgive me if it seems random and a bit trivial, but it's the best I can do here:

I love to read and my library card is one of my prize possessions
Some of my best childhood memories involve trips to the library with my mom. 
I take my boys to our library frequently and hope they'll have some of those same great memories.
I've grown a little more adventurous with food as I've aged and had a chance to travel. Though I still refuse to eat certain basics that you will find strange. 
My boys are my world and I take very seriously the responsibility of raising them. 
I desperately hope I'll be able to help mold them into responsible, respectful, kind, compassionate yet independent and strong young men. 
My favorite thing is to coach them in their various park district sports. Those practices and games are the most fun I have these days. 
I work in finance and have a somewhat stressful job and long commute. It is rewarding at times but also the source of my biggest regret, the time that it takes me away from home. 
Even though I work in finance, math has always been a weakness. I work hard not to let that show. 
I spend an hour each way on the train and hope you will help me fill that time with some interesting conversation. 
I try to be transparent and do my best not to judge others and I'm almost impossible to offend. 
Im organizationally challenged at times and as a result can seem non responsive or unconcerned with timeliness or deadlines. I'm working on that. Ha! 

That's probably enough for now. If you've managed to get through this entire email and still have some interest, please send a reply!

title: Drive For Our Bike Ride, Cross the USA for Free!
text:
I didn't know where to post this because we are looking for something different, as you will see. I listed a zip code because Craigslist required it.

We are two bicycle riders who plan on riding across the USA, from San Francisco to St. Petersburg, Florida, starting in June 2016 and ending mid to late August. (Yes, we know it will be HOT, but that it is when drivers are most likely available.)

We are looking for a c0-driver for a support vehicle (we already have a local 29 year old woman and she would like some company along the way) We will pay your travel, lodging, entertainment and food expenses during the trip. 

You will arrive in the San Francisco Bay Area where we are and we will drive to Los Angeles a few days before the June 14 start of our bike ride so that you can do some seeing there. In Los Angeles you will experience such sights as the Pacific Ocean, Venice Beach (a uniquely California experience), Korea Town, Hollywood and Beverly Hills. We then ride towards Palm Springs and on to the Grand Canyon (a wonder of the world and photos really do not do it justice). From there we will travel through such places as Flagstaff and Sedona, Arizona, Albuquerque, New Mexico (with its Native American culture), Santa Fe (one of the art capitals of the world), Carlsbad Caverns, Austin (probably the most progressive city in Texas), San Antonio (home of the Alamo and its river walk which doesn't rival Venice but is nonetheless fun), Baton Rouge, New Orleans (home of Cajun cooking and Mardi Gras) and finally St. Augustine (the oldest continuously occupied European settlement in the US). We will spend rest and visiting days in the more interesting places so it won't be just a "drive by" experience.

There will be boring stretches of vast expanses, but more importantly, you will have the chance to see more small town "Americana" than most Americans get to see while experiencing Tex-Mex food, parts of the "Old West," Louisiana, Florida and much more. We will take a different route driving back across the country to see different places, probably including Las Vegas. When we return to the San Francisco Bay Area you will get to see, of course, the Golden Gate Bridge, it's beautiful views, Sausalito, the Berkeley campus, and more if you want. 

Because the two of us will be riding our bikes going to Florida, your driving will only be from 100km to at most 200km (60 to, at the most, 115 miles) per day, with some days off for our rest and to visit places of interest. We would like you to do laundry once a week or so while we are riding as well as some food shopping and preparation (lunches, such as sandwiches) and help with planning our lodging and stops.

You need to be good natured, responsible, easy to get along with, speak English, have a valid driver's license and be able to get a visa to visit the USA if a visa is required. This is perfect for a college student, a recent graduate who doesn't yet have a job or possibly a teacher who wants to spend vacation time exploring.

In the photo, I am 2nd from the right and Nick is 4th from the right. 

We are 2 responsible professional men who live near San Francisco.

Let us know if you are interested.

Thank you, and here is to the adventure of a life time,

Rick

text: Yes I am married, but that doesn't mean that I shouldn't be able to meet new people and make new friends. This is not a veiled attempt at initiating any type of extra-marital fling but, rather, is simply emblematic of my need for a new outlet because, as horrible as it sounds, the whole family-life-thing can just suck the life out of you at times to the point where you no longer remember who you are as an individual (and please, I don't want to hear any grief about that statement because we have all been there at one time or another). Despite that dismal assessment of the status quo, I wouldn't give it up for the world and am not looking to change anything. It is simply that the "play-dates" for the kids aren't cutting it any more as far as social interaction and I can only spend so much time with my co-workers, and even my wife and I hardly have a minute to ourselves. Our conversations have devolved to the point where we don't talk about much else other than the kids and by the time they are in bed at night and we can relax we are just too tired to talk about anything meaningful. This doesn't mean that our marriage is bad, it just means that we are frazzled parents who devote all of our time and energy to the children without regard for our own lives. Most of the people with whom I work are single and much younger than I am, and I really don't want to spend a lunch hour hearing about their drunken exploits. I prefer to meet a woman simply because I have always gotten along better with women and can find more common ground. I am not one of those guys who can only talk about sports or sex and I am also not at the other extreme like a metro-sexual...I am just somewhere in between. I miss talking about current events, politics, a good book, life in general...

title: Needing to make a connection
text:
I have a Sony Blu-ray player with a USB port. It won't read my external hard drive. I'm pretty sure from the snippets of user questions I've seen on the net, I have been able to piece together that probably the USB port doesn't supply the needed power to it to spin the actual mechanical stuff.

If I'm wrong, please just tell me.

I have found hubs with external power sources (you can plug the hub right into the electric outlet on the wall in your house) on Amazon. It seems to me that this would fix the problem because the portable external hard drive would be powered from the hub and then the main cord on the hub could plug into the Blu-ray player USB port. I just am not sure about how much power is supplied. One of the items on Amazon said like 2 amps, one was 5 amps, one was 10 amps. Would any of these be sufficient? Would all of them be sufficient? I have no idea how to equate the amount of power I need to what is available for purchase.

My end goal is to be able to watch movies stored on the hard drive running the signal through the Blu-ray player to the TV.

If I should consider an easier way to achieve my end goal or if I should be considering some other way to do it just tell me.

So if you know how to make it all work together let me know. Even better, you can come show how to do it.

(seeing some of all that porn I have stored on the computer would be nice to be able to do as well, but don't think I am hunting for someone to watch along with. It's always welcome, but in this case I really am looking for your knowledge, so it won't matter if you are 21 or 121)

:)

Update: found an old externally powered external hard drive that connected by USB. It had some old videos on it. Not all formats worked with the Blu-ray player, but the one I needed does work, so that's good.
Also tried a powered hub that was not very old. It would not recognize that. So it seems that an externally powered drive will work, but not a powered hub. Maybe I don't know?
At least I am a little closer to what I needed to find out. I still need any advice that you have.

title: Need a Date for a Party? Event? New in Town? Or Just Bored?
text:
Hi. No. This isn't a joke. I'm a real guy. After hearing many of my friends and peers bemoaning the fact that they didn't have dates, boyfriends, etc. for the upcoming parties and events, I decided to put myself out there. Of course, already being friends, I didn't approach them about offering to take them out, but nonetheless I thought it might be a good, fun and intriguing idea that would make everyone happy.What does Rent-A-Gent do? I will be happy to accompany you to a party, event, night on the town, casual date or just sightseeing if you're new in town or just bored. I can pick you up or meet you there. You decide.Who is Rent-A-Gent and what might make him interesting or intriguing to you?
I am a 48-year-old caucasian straight male who is divorced
I am 6 foot 6 and weigh around 235 pounds
I have no facial hair, tats or piercings
I've been told I'm both imposing and approachable at the same time - probably because I have big shoulders, but also have a quick, easy smile and look like the guy-next-door
I have a Master's Degree
I can speak easily about virtually any subject - from politics to history to philosophy to sports
I won't get slobbery drunk and embarrass you in front of everyone
If we went to a party or an event, I would actually speak to your friends and 'mingle' instead of sitting sullenly by myself at the table
As a date, I can be as detached (just a friend) or as cozy to you as you wish me to
I will wear cologne - but not too much and it won't be AquaVelva
I won't try to make an unsolicited pass at you that would make things awkward
I would notice if you wore something new or changed cut/color of your hair
I'm as comfortable in a dive bar as I am in an Art Museum
I listen. I also talk, but I don't dominate the conversation. And I actually talk about the things you're interested in - which probably ISN'T Hunting, Fantasy Football or WWE. But hey, if you do like those things, I can talk about them as well
I'd like to think I have a great sense of humor which can range from silly and goofy to punny to dry and satirical
I can behave like a responsible adult or a carefree and spontaneous partner in crime
I drive a nice, new car so if I did pick you up, you wouldn't show up in a clunker
I don't wear tuxedos though. It just isn't my thing
Interested? Intrigued? Drop me a line and let's see if we can make our schedules fit.

Neither of us is looking for a permanent escape from our married lives. We both have busy, active lives, and understand the importance of family, and while we can enjoy our conversations together, our fun times will always take a back seat to maintaining our real world lives.

title: Does this ever cross your mind?
text: As a single person, do you ever look over at the car next to you at a red light and see an individual alone? Be it male or female, do you wonder if they are going through life hoping to come across that one person that warms their heart and brings a smile to their face with only the mere thought of that person and not being able to wait until the next time you hear their voice or their laugh? While I'm hoping to be unique in my post, I find that my message is not unlike the others, just worded differently. I don't really know what I am hoping will come from this post, but in an effort to be different, let me list what I can offer instead of what I am looking to find....a) a comforting shoulder and inviting arms when you've had a hard day, b) be a cheerleader for you in all of your efforts c) a motivator when you feel like giving up d) provide a laugh, if even at my own expense. I guess I've basically described being a friend. While I'm not looking to fall in love, I surely will not run from it if the right person happens to be cruising through CL and finds my post. title: Married looking for Married Bromance
text:
First- Lets define Bromance: The contemporary circumstances of bromance separate it from more general homosocial practices and historic romantic friendships.[3][4] Aristotle's classical description of friendship is often taken to be the prototype of the bromance. He wrote around 330 BC, "It is those who desire the good of their friends for the friends' sake that are most truly friends, because each loves the other for what he is, and not for any incidental quality." Numerous examples exist of famous intense male friendships throughout most of Western history, and such relationships were likewise common.

Friendships among males are often primarily based on shared activities. This can include playing video games, staying overnight, sharing common objectives, chatting by the fire, watching movies, fishing, camping, and other sporting activities, gambling, social drinking. title: A chance to apologize please
text:
It was last Saturday and I was at the bar. My shitty boss made me work late Friday and then early Saturday morning. Then I was laid off at the end of the day. Needless to say I was pretty upset and in need of a good long night at the bar.?

I got there straight from work at 6.30 and sat at the bar. You were a few stools down and there was a few people between us. About 11.30 there was only a few of us left and you moved down to the stool next to me and we casually chatted for the next hour before you started making advances at me. First off, I was very drunk at this point. That's important for you to understand.?

Now, one of two things went horribly wrong here. Either I was so drunk that anything I said was impossible to understand or you were too drunk to put two and two together. You see, when I kept saying things like "thank you but I'm not like that" and "I'm not gay" it's because I thought you were a man. So naturally when you(who I thought was a man) tried to kiss me I believed it was time to fight and I punched you. I admit I SHOULD NOT have tried any wwe moves after that but I'm not a very good fighter and I was in attack mode.?

Enter the large biker type guys playing pool in the back. If I would have known they were your brothers, I would've made out with you even if I thought you were a dude. Long story short, I hope that my 3 broken ribs and my missing tooth(it's right in the front by the way) are enough to make us even. I would still like to be friends and hopefully we can look back on this and laugh one day. I don't want to date but we can drink beer and lift weights or fish or something. Hope to hear from you.

Are you married or attached and looking for something more? Has your relationship lost it's spark, does each day feel the same? Do you walk through the mall, a supermarket, or down the street and wish you could approach interesting or attractive people without seeming like a desperate stalker?

If so, you and I may share some common ground. I am looking for a mutually respectful friendship with the potential to grow into a long lasting friendship. title: Are you a married mom, seeking a virtual friendship?
text:
I'm not exactly sure why I'm posting this, but here goes. If you're a married mother of younger kids, sometimes wanting to have a close friend to talk to, and not looking for anything physical but essentially an online connection, our situations might be similar. Do you feel like you have things to say, but sometimes keep them to yourself; not because they're highly personal but maybe your spouse just doesn't hear you? You do have friends, but you still feel there's a certain kind of connection that's missing, something you'd like to explore? If all of that's hard to put your finger on, it sounds like me.

I'm married, in my 40's, have younger children, educated, well traveled, creative, and generally have a happy life. But I sometimes miss having as many friends as I used to before marriage. It would be nice to connect with someone who is in a similar situation, would like to have an open dialogue about things, maybe personal, maybe topical. Are you intelligent, articulate? If so, I would like to start this friendship by emailing and see if we click. Again, I cannot over stress the "platonic" nature of this friendship, as there is no way I'm looking to change my situation or anyone else's. If this sounds like something that you might be interested in, please write me back. I would appreciate if you start of by telling a little bit about yourself, and what made you respond to my post. If interested, in the subject line please write the color of panties you last wore..smiles!

Like me, you have no interest in changing your home situation, but have an implicit need to pursue a connection that supplements, energizes, and enhances your already charmed life. You appreciate that such a connection is intellectual in nature and, though it comes with absolutely no expectations of morphing into anything else, is open and honest and bound only by the constraints that we invent.
